reviewText:
Dwarfs!? is a strangely addicting game. If you enjoy arcade games, where the main objective is to beat your high score (or someone else's high score), you'll probably love this game.

The way you score is by getting as much gold as you can, while trying to stay alive--but, you're dwarfs aren't the brightest and will insist on digging into caves filled with water, lava, and monsters, so you'll have to keep a close eye on them, which becomes harder and harder as the game progresses.

The F2P version has the two easier difficulties unlocked and each can be played in 5, 15, 30, and 60 min sessions (but beware, you cannot save the game mid-session).

The only problem I've encountered is in long games, where you have thousands of dwarfs in the field at one time, my computer starts to lag--which makes the game very difficult and frustrating to play.

Overall, this is a fun, simple, casual game that can keep you entertained for hours or opened for a quick 5-minute session.

[NOTE: If you buy the full version, your personal scores and achievements will transfer, but the F2P version has different global leaderboards, and your global score will not transfer.]

[EDIT: For those wondering, I personally own the full version (non-F2P), which is why my play-time on the F2P version is so low.]


Concerning the DLC...
Dwarfs - F2P Skirmish Pack (Recommended): Comes with 3 modes (Sandbox, Rush, and Dark). Rush and Dark modes bring new challenges to the game and can be a lot of fun. In Sandbox, you can experiment. In Rush, dwarfs spawn CONSTANTLY and you can only let 200 die. In Dark, you cannot see where caves or minerals are located.

Dwarfs - F2P Difficulty Pack (Recommended): Unlocks the two harder difficulty levels (Hardcore & Tedi Hardcore) for Arcade mode.

Dwarfs - F2P Endless Mode Pack (Not Recommended): Exactly like Arcade mode, except it's endless and you're allowed to pick the map size as well as the difficulty. Beware lag. Also, no high score is recorded.

Dwarfs - F2P Summer Carnival Pack (Extremely NOT Recommended): Was a prize for a Steam summer sale years ago; a very simple mini-game that is completely different than the base game.

Dwarfs - F2P Base Defend Pack (Not Recommended): A cute little tower defense mode that's rather different from the base game.

reviewText:
This is a great game.

Despite not having all of the content of the paid version, there is still much fun to be had. I have played for over an hour, and I made a video for it on my YouTube channel. It's a game that takes from many other games, and is a great RTS.

WARNING! THIS REVIEW MAY CONTAIN WHAT YOU BELIEVE TO BE SPOILERS! PROCEED WITH CAUTION, FELLOW DWARF!

You are the dwarf overseer, and you see what the dwarfs be doing. If they start doing something you don't like...
STOP THEM!
This game does require a legitimate strategy, and due to the system of caves that appear, you never know if something will make you the richest dwarf in existence, or doom you and your hall. A dangerous cave can be many blocks away from the town hall, and depending on the danger inside, you can have an entire minute to deal with the situation at your own pace before it becomes a worrying threat. Sometimes you will uncover enemies. This can be a troop of 2 spiders, to 3 orcs and to a powerful warlock. To truly tackle these requires you to use fighter dwarves, which are very powerful fighters (and good miners). They cost 100 gold each (which by the time you encounter enemies you will have enough of), and are instantly available to fight.

You can place a battle tower in an area that you have mined for 500 gold, and this is VITAL to beating powerful enemies such as the warlock, as you can have up to 8 enemies. Of course, in a five minute arcade play-through, you may not need this. But in a 60 minute play through, you definitely will.

My one complaint is that you can't zoom out enough to view the whole arena at once, and this can be annoying when you have a load of dwarfs doing there own thing on multiple ends of the map. This has lead to many deaths in my playthroughs.

Overall, I give this game a 9/10.

And to top it all off, this game has a cameo from the ultimate dwarf: Yogscast Simon! :D

I love it AND IT'S FREE TO PLAY i think everyone should take a break and give this game a try seriously give it a try RATING: 100/100\n

In Dwarfs!? you play the 'Dwarf Overseer' over your Dwarf's mining. The game is pretty simple.
There are only two types of buildings and only two types of dwarf's.
There are miner dwarf's and warrior dwarf's. Miners spawn automatically as you get more gold. Warrior's are obviously more adept to fight can be spawned at the main base (max 8) or, be spawned from the other building type, outposts.

The aim of the game is to get as much gold as you can within the time limit or before your base is destroyed. The miners will dig around randomly but you can guide them to caves or minerals. However, giving them directions costs precious gold. This is where it gets incredibly fun. There are really not that many different types of hazardous areas. There's caves full of water or lava that can flood your mine and there are caves full of enemies. What's fun is that you won't see what's in the cave until a dwarf has dug into it. But the caves may have treasure within and gold is what keeps your mine in order.

Once a dwarf has discovered a cave full of water or lava it you need to block it off with a wall, blow up a pit with dynamite (which require sacrificing a dwarf) and then solidify the rock around the area so your miners don't blindly spring another leak. These caves are certainly the most hazardous, especially when your mine has branched into something quite complex where water could be flowing through several shafts which all need blocked off.

Caves with enemies can be dealt with warriors. You can build an outpost where you can spawn 4 warriors, train them and (best of all) shoot them out a cannon towards the enemy area. Shooting them out the cannon isn't accurate so you may get a dwarf or 2 in shafts without enemies. Again, this is where gold is much needed. Being able to build outposts allows you to be tactful with the placement.

It's all really easy to control with shortcuts to items being labelled at the bottom, it's very easy to pick up and play. There are also time controls. You can pause the game for a brief moment, if things are getting a bit hectic, to look around and work with your mine. Best of all is the ability to speed up the game. It allows you to be as greedy as you can be. Both these controls don't affect your time limit per game. Which is perfect as these are tools to help your mine rather than alter the match itself.

The F2P version probably has what most people want. You are only limited to Easy and Normal difficulties but Normal is good enough. There's no reason why people shouldn't give this a go. The game also features some humorous tutorials with a dwarf voiced by Yogscast's Simon which was a nice surprise. With games being timed from 15 minutes, 30 minutes or an hour, it is certainly a lot of fun to pick up and play.
Fun for broke people.\n

reviewText: This is a game for people who think fast and act faster. The player does not have complete control over the dwarfs mining; you may guide some of their actions but ultimately you will have too many of them to guide every single one and then they'll dig in whatever direction they want. Your job is to guide them to gems and precious metals and see to it that they don't dig into caves with lava or water, thus flooding the cave and killing all dwarfs. To avoid floods, you have to block or blow holes in the ground. This, however, comes at a cost and thus is one of the reasons to why you have to find gems and precious metals early in the game.\n\nThe game's graphics has an old look to them, with a horrendously old-fashioned main menu design, which put me off at first. As most who know me know the Dwarves are one of my favorite fantasy races as I tend to identify with them quite a bit. This game is pretty simple but a lot of fun.

Basically you pick a time limit for yourself (up to an hour) and see just how gigantic a mine you can make with your little bearded buddies. You build defensive outposts, guide miners towards mineral nodes, block off water-filled caves and volcanic caves before they can hurt your men, and so on. Simple enough but the town hall is constantly spawning more miners who dig faster and faster as they level up. What starts out small becomes a gigantic mining complex in a surprisingly short amount of time.

Its definitely worth a try and, hey, the price is right. :P

This game is frustratingly fun and highly addictive! Arcade mode let's you choose a time limit and then from there it's a race against the clock. A race to collect as much money as possible while building forts, dodging lava, avoiding floods... and Minions... enemy minions! lol

Let me get started. As an idea, this works. You control dwarfs that will mine into caves filled with either treasure or tragedy, and also get gold. You can build towers to get warrior dwarfs, who will fight off goblins when your digger dwarfs mine a cave full of them. You can play a round for up to an hour.

And this would be a great game... if the dwarf digger AI wasn't so stupid.

I mean, you bust open a cave full of water, you put a wall down, should be good. But for some reason, digger dwarfs think it's a good idea to mine through your walls even if you placed it to block lava right in front of them. Water poured into my base and I started getting spammed with messages of a group of 10 dwarfs trying to break through the walls every 2 seconds.

You can't explore or fight when you need to keep babysitting dwarfs that can't realise that walls aren't something to stick their pickaxes through. Your best bet is to hold CTRL and create unbreakable walls around said problem, but here's where that doesn't work:

The lava is pouring into your base. You've already sacraficed a decent dwarf to create the hole to divert the lava's flow. And then, it heads for your base from many directions. You can't make unbreachable walls out of nowhere as you can walls, so if it happens, you might as well let it pour right in. Otherwise the game will be incredibly dull and boring as you lead the suicide diggers away from their doom.

I don't know why this is around Â£10. It should be free for all of it, no microtransactions. Get Dungeon Keeper, not this.
